abstract.p: A new algorithm is proposed based on semi-analytical methods to solve the conjugate heat transfer problems. In this respect, a problem of conjugate forced-convective flow over a heat-conducting plate is modeled and the integro-differential equation occurring in the problem is solved by two lately-proposed approaches, Adomian decomposition method and differential transform method. The solution of the governing integro-differential equation for temperature distribution of the plate is handled more easily and accurately by implementing Adomian decomposition method/differential transform method rather than other traditional methods such as perturbation method. A numerical approach is also performed via finite volume method to examine the validity of the results for temperature distribution of the plate obtained by Adomian decomposition method/differential transform method. It is shown that the expressions for the temperature distribution in the plate obtained from the two methods, Adomian decomposition method and differential transform method, are the same and show closer agreement to the results calculated from numerical work in comparison with the expression obtained by perturbation method existed in the literature.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The problems of the mutual thermal effect of the solid body and the fluid flow on the heat exchanging between them, i.e. conjugate heat-transfer problems, have received many attentions. Due to the fact that the temperature distribution of the plate and that of the flow is coupled, the arising problems are complex. The phrase conjugate heat transfer was used for the first time by Perelman,1 who applied the method of the asymptotic solution to solve the integral equations occurring in conjugate problems. Luikov et al.2 presented an analytical but complex solution for the semi-infinite plate using a generalized Fourier sine transform. Chida and Katto3 used the vectorial dimensional analysis to study the conjugate heat transfer problem. The solution for conjugate heat transfer in a circular tube was obtained by Nagasue4 on the basis of the superposition principle and by the use of Green function. The process of the external heating of a flat plate under a convective flow was studied by Trevino and Linan,5 with inclusion of the axial heat conduction through the plate. The two limits of a conducting plate and a bad conducting plate were analyzed through the application of a regular perturbation procedure for the first case and a singular perturbation technique for the latter. Olek6 used special eigen-function expansion to derive an exact solution for heat transfer in laminar flow of a non-Newtonian fluid inside a circular or parallel-plate duct, including axial heat conduction. A combined experimental and numerical study of conjugate heat transfer was conducted by Chiu et al.7 for a horizontal channel heated from below. Kanna and Das8 carried out an analytical solution for forced convection heat transfer from a laminar plane wall jet as conjugate case.

Numerical and numerical–analytical solutions of the conjugate heat/mass transfer from a finite flat plate has also been performed by many authors in the recent years.9–13 For example, Mobedi9 carried out a numerical investigation to evaluate the effect of conduction of horizontal walls on natural convection heat transfer in a square cavity. A code based on vorticity–stream function was written to solve the governing equations simultaneously over the entire computational domain. Juncu10 used the finite difference method to investigate the transient, conjugate, forced convection heat/mass transfer from a finite flat plate to a steady stream of viscous, incompressible fluid. Mamun et al.11 studied the effects of magnetic field, viscous dissipation and heat generation on natural convection flow of an incompressible, viscous and electrically conducting fluid along a vertical flat plate in the presence of conduction with the help of the finite difference method. Bula and Vasquez12 obtained the interface temperature for the problem of conjugate heat transfer over a flat plate using the Chebyshev polynomial approximation. Escandon et al.13 solved, numerically and asymptotically, the steady-state analysis of a conjugate heat transfer process in an electro-osmotic and fully developed laminar flow including Joule heating effects.

The complicated equations in the study of conjugate heat transfer problems have caused complexities and restrictions for the classical and mathematical methods. So far, the presented analytical solutions have not been able to provide an easily calculated formula to prescribe the heat transfer characteristics of the problems. But in the recent years, some semi-analytical methods have been introduced for solving such complex equations. For example, the perturbation method is one well-known method. But existence of a small parameter has restricted the method, and some new methods have been recently presented to eliminate that restriction. Among them, the homotopy analysis method (HAM),14,15 the variational iteration method (VIM),16 the differential transform method (DTM)17 and the Adomian decomposition method (ADM)18 has been widely developed for solving linear and non-linear differential equations in heat transfer. For example, Moghimi et al.14 applied HAM to present an analytical solution for a Marangoni mixed convection boundary layer flow. They demonstrated that the method can obtain an expression that is acceptable for all values of effective parameters and is also able to control the convergence of the solution. Chang18 presented a solution based on ADM to obtain a solution for fins with temperature-dependent surface heat flux. He found ADM fast and accurate for solving the problem.

Also in the recent years, Adomian decomposition method19–21 and differential transform method22,23 have been proven to be very efficient in obtaining approximate solutions of a wide class of integro-differential equations. For example, Bougoffa et al.19 transformed the linear and non-linear Abel integral equations in such a manner that the Adomian decomposition method can be applied and the results obtained indicated the approach was indeed practical and efficient. Volterra integral equations with separable kernels were solved using the differential transform method by Zaid.22 He reported the reliability, and the performances of the differential transform method.

To our best of knowledge, the integro-differential equations occurring in conjugate heat transfer problems have not been so far attacked by the semi-analytical methods such as the HPM, HAM, VIM, DTM, ADM and other modified methods. Therefore, relying on the promising reports of the ADM and DTM operability for solving integro-differential equations in the recent years,19–23 the present work is motivated by the desire to examine the operability of the methods for solving the integro-differential equations occurring in conjugate heat transfer problems. To do this, ADM and DTM are implemented to solve the problem of conjugate forced convection flow over a conducting plate so as to evaluate the temperature distribution of a conducting plate and Nusselt number of the flow, when the plate has a finite thickness. In order to verify the results obtained by the ADM/DTM, the results are compared with those attained with numerical analysis. Finally, the results are compared with the approximate relation existed in the literature. In the results and discussion section, the physical characteristics of the problem are also discussed in details.

sec.title: Mathematical description of the problem
sec.p:
Contemplate Figure 1 in which conjugate force convection flow takes place over a conducting solid plate. The variation of the flow properties along the z-direction is neglected. Therefore the flow and the plate are considered to be two-dimensional. For the sake of simplicity, the thickness of the plate is assumed sufficiently smaller than the plate length such that the temperature variation along the y-direction can be also neglected. The lower surface of the plate is heated under uniform and constant heat flux, q″,and there is no heat generation inside the solid plate. The incompressible fluid is flowing over the upper surface of the plate. The flow is assumed laminar, steady and two-dimensional in x–y plane with the free stream of velocity, U∞, and free stream temperature, T∞. The left and the right sides of the rectangular plate are insulated whereas a constant heat flux is traveling through the bottom side toward the top of the plate. The upper side of the solid makes direct contact with the flowing fluid and heat transfer to the fluid occurs via this surface. Due to the complexities of the problem, a number of simplifications are considered. For example it is assumed that the effects of buoyancy and viscous dissipation are negligible and the physical properties of the material of the plate and the fluid are uniform, isotropic and constant. Owing to the fact that the finite thickness of the plate, b, results in the generation of the axial heat conduction in the opposite direction of the flow, the heat flux distribution on the upper surface, q″u,varies with that at the bottom, q″,and may be evaluated by the following classical expression.24 (1)q″u(x)=0.332kfxPr13Rex12{∫0x[1-(ξx)34]-13dTsdξdξ+ΔT0}

The first term in equation (1) is related to the integration of the temperature variation along the plate and the second term corresponds to the temperature jump in the leading edge of the plate, ΔT0. x is a distance measured from the leading edge and kf is the thermal conductivity of fluid. Besides, ⪻ is the Prandtl number and the local Reynolds number, Rex is defined as (2)Rex=U∞xν

Applying the energy balance in an elemental control volume of width, dx and height, b over the conducting solid plate (thermally lumped element along the plate thickness) leads to the relation (3)q″+kb∂2T∂x2=q″u(x) where q″u is calculated from equation (1). To formulate the problem under study, it is necessary to define the following dimensionless variables (4)(ξ∧,x∧)=(ξ,x)L; T∧(x∧)=0.332Pr1/3ReL1/2(Ts-T∞)q″L/kf and also (5)κ=(10.332)(kskf)(bL)Pr-1/3ReL-1/2

This parameter represents the ratio of the ability of the plate to carry heat in the streamwise direction to the ability of the fluid to carry heat from the plate. For a conducting plate, this parameter must be in the order of unity or higher.5 Combining equations (1) to (5), the governing equation for dimensionless temperature distribution of the conducting plate can be obtained as (6)x∧(1+κ∂2T∧∂x∧2)=T∧0+∫0x∧[1-(ξ∧x∧)34]-13∂T∧∂ξ∧dξ∧
With the boundary conditions (7)∂T∧∂x∧|x∧=0=0 (8)∂T∧∂x∧|x∧=1=0

The solution of equation (6) is difficult to be traced directly and we have to solve the equation by means of the recursive methods. ADM and DTM, as reliable recursive methods to find a quick and highly accurate solution of such equations, are described in the next part.

sec.title: Basic concepts of ADM and DTM
sec.p: The basic definitions and the fundamental theorems of the ADM and DTM plus its applicability for some types of integro-differential equations are given in Bougoffa et al.,19 Wazwaz,20 Hashim,21 Zaid22 and Arikoglu and Ozkol.23 For the convenience of the reader and without loss of generality, the basic concepts of Adomian decomposition method and differential transform method are described as following.

sec.title: ADM
sec.p: Consider an integro-differential equation (9)T∧(m)(x)=f(x)+∫0xK(x,ξ)F(T∧(ξ))dξ where T∧(m)(x) indicates the mth derivative of T∧(x), and F(T∧(ξ)) is a function. In addition, the kernel K(x,ξ) and f(x) are given in advance. It is of interest to point out that T∧(x) and f(x) are assumed real and as many times differentiable as required for x∈[0,L]. Integrating both sides of equation (9) in the interval [0, x] m times, equation (9) can be rewritten as (10)T∧(x)-T∧(0)=L-1[f(x)]+L-1[∫0xK(x,ξ)F(T∧(ξ))dξ] where L is assumed invertible and L-1 is an m-fold integral operator. The standard Adomian method25 defines the solution T(x) by the series (11)T∧(x)=∑κ=0NT∧κ(x) where, for larger values ofN faster convergence is achieved. The components T∧0, T∧1, T∧2, … can be determined recursively by using the following modified recursive relation26 (12)T∧0=T∧(0)T∧1=L-1[f(x)]T∧k+1=L-1[∫0xK(x,ξ)F(T∧k)dξ]; k≥1

sec.title: DTM
sec.p:
The differential transform of a functionf(x) is defined as (13)f~(k)=(1k!)dkf(x)dxk|x=x0=0 where f(x) stands for the original function and f~(k) is the differential transform function. The inverse differential transform of a sequence, f~(k) is defined as (14)f(x)=∑k=0∞f~(k)(x-x0)k which implies that the concept of differential transform is derived from Taylor series expansion. However, the derivatives in the Taylor series expansion are calculated by an iterative way, which is described by the differential transformed equations of the original function and the method does not suffer from the difficulty of evaluating the derivatives symbolically. For implementation purposes, a finite series is chosen instead of equation (14) and the approximate relation is rewritten as (15)f(x)≈∑k=0Nf~(k)(x-x0)k where, for larger values ofN faster convergence is achieved. Solving these recurrence relations for T∧0, T∧1, T∧2, … , and using series solution equation (11) for ADM or differential inverse transform, equation (15) for DTM, the expression for temperature distribution of the conducting plate can be determined.

sec.title: Numerical approach
sec.p:
In this part, a numerical approach is presented to verify the results obtained from the ADM/DTM. Two computational domains, fluid domain and solid domain, as shown in Figure 2 are considered. In the numerical simulation the flow over the plate is assumed to be two-dimensional and the variations of the flow properties along the z-direction are neglected. In the solid domain, the assumption mentioned in the section ‘Mathematical description of the problem’, that the plate temperature varies in only x-direction, is discarded and a two-dimensional mesh and solution (in x and y directions) are considered to more carefully and accurately simulate the physical problem. Figure 2 shows that a small number of computation cells are used for the plate, since it is assumed to be thin and the temperature gradients are small. Figure 2.
Computational domains and the mesh system.
The conservation equations for mass and momentum are (25)∂u∂x+∂v∂y=0 (26)ρ(u∂u∂x+v∂u∂y)=μ∂2u∂y2

The energy conservation equations are (27)ρcp(u∂Tf∂x+v∂Tf∂y)=kf∂2Tf∂y2 and, (28)∂2Ts∂x2+∂2Ts∂y2=0. where the subscripts s and f denote respectively solid and fluid local temperature. The boundary conditions associated with equations (25) to (28) are (29)u=v=0aty=0u=U∞,Tf=T∞atx=0∂Ts∂x=0,atx=0andx=L-ks∂Ts∂y=q″,aty=-b, together with the symmetry boundary conditions, ∂u∂y=0 and ∂Tf∂y=0 at the top edge of the fluid domain, and the coupled boundary conditions at the interface of the two domains (y = 0) (30)Tf=Tsks∂Ts∂y=kf∂Tf∂y

Finite volume approach is used to convert the governing partial differential equations into the system of discrete algebraic equations. SIMPLEC (SIMPLE-consistent) method is utilized to solve the system of discrete algebraic equations, since the method aids in convergence speed-up for laminar flows. Second-order discretization of the governing equations is selected for flow and energy equations. Also the convergence criterion for all the equations is considered to be of the order of 10−8. Such high order discretization schemes and tight convergence criteria are desirable for accurate resolution of the boundary layer. The mesh system in the fluid domain is non-uniform in x and y directions, such that in the vicinity of the wall and in the beginning of the boundary layer the mesh system is finer when compared to that in the other regions. The purpose of such a fine mesh is to capture the sharp gradients in hydraulic and thermal boundary layers. A schematic of the mesh system is shown in Figure 2. The appropriate mesh size is determined by successive refinements of each mesh size to four times that of the previous mesh size until the criterion |(T∧j-T∧j-1)/T∧j|<10-5 is satisfied. Here, T∧j represents the temperature calculated using each mesh size, and T∧j-1 corresponds to the temperature using the previous mesh size. Following this procedure, excellent independency of the solution with respect to the mesh size is achieved and the results are performed by using between 40,000 and 60,000 nodes for the fluid domain and between 1000 and 2000 nodes for the solid domain. To verify the results of present numerical solution, the numerical results for the temperature distribution of the plate under non-conjugate forced convection flow (flow over a zero thickness plate, κ=0) are compared with the temperature distribution existed in Bejan.24 This comparison is shown in Table 2. It is seen that good agreement has been obtained; however, it must be noted that there is a deviation in the temperature distribution at the vicinity of the leading edge of the plate, which arises as a result of discontinuity existed in the leading edge of the plate. sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
In section ‘Solution of the problem’, it was shown that the two methods, ADM and DTM, predict the same expression for temperature distribution of the conducting plate. In Table 3, the temperature distribution of the conducting plate using the numerical analysis are compared with the results obtained from ADM/DTM and perturbation method5 at several values of N when κ=1. Table 4 shows the comparison between the results obtained by the numerical analysis and the ones obtained by the ADM/DTM for κ=5. As it is seen, good agreement between the three approaches and excellent trend of convergence for ADM/DTM are achieved; however, larger errors are associated with the results obtained from perturbation method5 when compared with the results of ADM/DTM for (N=11). In Figure 6(a) to (c), the plate temperature distribution, the Nusselt number and the heat flux distribution at the upper surface of the plate are compared between the cases of conjugate and non-conjugate convection heat transfer, κ=1 and κ=0, respectively. Figure 6(a) shows that the temperature distribution of the conjugate convection heat transfer becomes flatter than the one of the non-conjugate convection heat transfer. Figure 6(b) shows that the Nusselt number of the conjugate convection heat transfer is smaller than the one of the non-conjugate convection heat transfer. Figure 6(b) also shows that as we move along the flow direction the difference between the Nusselt number of the conjugate and non-conjugate convection heat transfer becomes more pronounced. Although the Nusselt number of the conjugate case is smaller than that of the non-conjugate case; however, the temperature distribution of the conjugate case is flatter than the one of the non-conjugate case. It is worth noting that in the case of having constant total heat transfer (q″A) achieving flatter temperature distribution and as a consequence, lower temperature of hot spot, is more significant than having greater Nusselt number. It is concluded from Figure 6(c) that for a conducting plate with a finite thickness (κ=1), the distribution of the heat flux at the upper surface is significantly affected by the plate thickness, especially in the vicinity of the leading edge of the plate when compared to that for non-conjugate flow. This means that the heat conduction in the axial direction of the body of plate carries the heat in the opposite direction of the flow. Therefore the heat flux which is uniformly induced to the lower surface of the plate is partially removed from the upper surface, higher at the vicinity of the leading edge of the plate and lower at elsewhere. Since the convective heat transfer coefficient of the leading edge of the plate is much greater than the ones at elsewhere, therefore the affected heat flux distribution at the upper surface by the plate thickness is in the favor of more effective heat transfer by convection mechanism. sec.title: Summary and conclusions
sec.p: In this study, the effectiveness and accuracy of the semi-analytical methods, ADM and DTM, are examined for solving the integro-differential equations occurring in conjugate heat transfer problems. A conjugate convective flow over a conducting plate is considered and the two methods are implemented to obtain the temperature distribution of the plate and Nusselt number of the flow. A numerical approach is also performed via the finite volume method to verify the results obtained by the ADM/DTM. It is shown that the two methods, ADM and DTM, predict the same expression for temperature distribution of the conducting plate. The comparison of the results obtained by numerical method for temperature distribution and the Nusselt number, with those obtained by ADM/DTM and with the results obtained by the perturbation5 revealed that the results of the ADM/DTM are closer to the results of the numerical method than the ones obtained by perturbation method.5 A monotonic convergence of the results using the ADM/DTM towards the numerical results is achieved when the number of components in the series solution is increased. Also it was shown that for larger values of the ratio of the ability of the plate to carry heat in the streamwise direction to that of the fluid, more rapid convergence is achieved. The important physical conclusion of the present study is that, if a heated plate cooled by forced convection flow, has a finite thickness, the hot spot temperature in the plate could be reduced than the case it has no thickness (a very thin plate).

The promising report of the present work about the operability of semi-analytical methods such as ADM and DTM, for solving conjugate heat transfer problems can motivate the readers to examine the operability of the method for other types of conjugate heat transfer problems such as the flows inside the tubes with conducting wall. The two-dimensional analysis of the conduction in the plate that was not considered in this work can also be studied.
